_header: Lordings quod he in churches when I preach
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the Pardoner’s Prologue of the Canterbury Tales — 136 lines in couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
LOrdynges quod he in chirche whan I precheI peyne me to haue an
                    hauten speche…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…which I am wonte to preche for to wynnenow holdith youre pees
                    my tale I wol bigynne
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And next / folwyng bigynneth his tale Radix malorum est
                        cupiditas (f. 240v); the Pardoner (RT)

BodBar20.First Lines:
Lordynges quod he in chirche when I precheI pyne me to haue a
                    hauteyn speche…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…Wiche Iames went to preche for to wynneNow holdeth ȝoure
                    pees my tale I wil begynne

Bod414.First Lines:
[L]Ordinges coth he in church when I precheI peyne me to haue an
                    haute speche…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…Which I am wont to preche forto wynneNow holdith your peas my
                    tale I wil begyn

Bod686.First Lines:
Lordinges quod he in chirche whenne y precheI peyne me to han an
                    hauten speche…
Bod686.Last Lines:
…Which y am wonte to preche for to wynneNow holde youre pees
                    my tale y wol bygynne
Bod686.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth the Prologe of þe pardoners tale / Radix omnium
                        malorum est cupiditas ad Timotheum 6o (f. 152v,
                    foot); Perdonere (RT); Here endeth the Prologe of the Perdoners / tale…
                    (f. 154v)

BodHatDon1.Last Lines:
…Which I am wont to preche for to wynNow hold your pees my
                    tale I wil begyn
BodHatDon1.Attributed Title:
Here beginneth þe Prolog of the Pardoner Radix omnium / malorum est
                        cupiditas Ad Timotheum vto (f. 157); The Pardonere (RT); Here
                    endeth the Prolog of the Pardoner… (f. 158v)

                    grauntid on to me…

                    pes myn tale I wele begyne

                    his prolog… (f. 163)

                    forto wynne
